_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Utilize MDA forms for maintenance inspections on equipment
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: piping, valves, pumps, storage tanks, nurse tanks, etc.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Farm Service
77 Cedar Street
Easton, MN 56025

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:
The Coop board, management and employees at Central Farm Service (CFS), 77 Cedar Street, Easton, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information and Regulated Substance:
The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, handled and distributed for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients. The facility has one 18,000 gallon storage tank and two 30,000 gallon storage tanks for a maximum quantity of BULK ammonia storage of approximately 363,776 pounds. The two 30,000 gallon tanks are manifolded. A second 18,000 gallon tank is on site but not in use. There are approximately 175,825 pounds of additional storage available in 1,000 and 1,450 gallon nurse tanks. The maximum quantity handled at one time would be the unloading of a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.
There are zero (0) dedicated employees at the facility. Up to 10 employees may work on the site periodically throughout the year.

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
The facility has implemented Minnesota Department of Agriculture rules, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility is required to conduct a semi-annual inspection of all bulk and nurse tank equipment, including load and unload equipment, and perform any needed mainten

ance to the equipment found during the inspections.

4. The Five-year Accident History:
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years on site that have:
a.	Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or
b.	To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

5. Release Scenarios
a.	Worst Case Release Scenario
The worst-case scenario is a release of the entire contents from the largest storage vessel (30,000 gallons, 279,828 pounds) over a 10-minute timeframe. EPAs RMP Comp was used to model the release. The following assumptions were used for the model: wind speed 1.5 meters/second and atmospheric stability class F ( both are default assumptions per https://www.epa.gov/rmp/atmospheric-conditions-used-site-consequence-analyses) and a rural setting. Modeled results indicate potential impact radius of 9.7 miles, in which there is an estimated population of 5,007 people, schools, residences, recreational areas, and commercial, office, and/or industrial areas.

b.	Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario is a release caused by an onsite vehicular accident that ruptures a 1-inch diameter product pipe. Gas is released for 2 minutes at a rate of 2,500 lbs/minute, or 5,000 pounds. EPAs RMP Comp was used to model the release. The following assumptions were used for the model: wind speed 3 meters/second and atmospheric stability class D (both are default assumptions per https://www.epa.gov/rmp/atmospheric-conditions-used-site-consequence-analyses), and a rural setting. Modeled results indicate potential impact radius of 0.9 miles, in which there is an estimated population of 204 people, residences, and commercial, office, and/or industrial areas.

6. Emergency Response Program:
The facility has:
a.	A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR 68.95. The plan incl

udes a specific section on NH3 Releases and what to do in the event of a release. Additional emergency response training is also provided at three other training sessions held at CFS on an annual basis. One of these three sessions is held each fall and is just on anhydrous ammonia safety.
b.	Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);
c.	Coordinated with local emergency responders.
d.	A Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan information for quick access and reference.
e.	A Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community in which we operate.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety: Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Currently, there are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation.
